Authors:
Ivona Kautmanova, Michal Tomsovsky, M. P. Martin, Margarita
Duenas
Title:
European species of Clavaria (Agaricales, Agaricomycetes)
with dark coloured basidiomata  morphological and molecular study
Journal: Persoonia: Molecular Phylogeny and Evolution of Fungi
Keywords:
Europe, fungi, LSU nrDNA, spore measurements,
phylogeny
Abstract:
Clavaria species with dark coloured basidiomata occurring
in Europe were analyzed using morphological and molecular methods.
Morphological analyses revealed four groups involving seven Clavaria
species with dark-coloured basidiomata. Phylogenetic analysis of LSU
nrDNA region confirmed separated positions of all seven Clavaria species
within the genus. All sequences are grouped in four well supported
clades mostly corresponding to defined morphological species. Results of
molecular study disprove infrageneric classification of Clavaria based
on presence or absence of clamps on bases of basidia and two widely
accepted subgenera subgen. Clavaria and subgen Holocoryne appear to be
polyphyletic. New approach in species delimitation is presented: (1) C.
asperulospora and C. atrofusca are two distinct species recognized by
the shape of spores, C. neonigrita is possible synonym of C.
asperulospora; (2) species with clustered fragile basidiomata C. fumosa
and C. cf. fuscoferruginea almost identical in shape and size of spores,
differing only in consistently and comparatively darker basidiomata of
the latter, are phylogenetically unrelated. (3) C. atrobadia is a
dubious species, probably a synonym of C. fuscoferruginea; (4) two
species with close morphological and phylogenetic affinity, C.
atroumbrina and C. pullei, are distinguished here based on more oblong
and narrower spores of the first. Comparison of European and North
American material confirmed transatlantic character of distribution of
C. asperulospora, C. atroumbrina, and C. fumosa.
